title: 113_hr5318
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Label and Transport Tissues Safely Act of 2014" or the "LATTS Act of 2014." It pertains to labeling and transporting tissues safely. The "Label and Transport Tissues Safely Act of 2014" requires a tissue bank license for introducing human tissue specimens into interstate commerce for medical research or education. Each package must be labeled with the proper name of the tissue, source tissue bank information, unique donor identifier, tissue type, cause of death, and serological test results. Each package of human tissue specimen must be labeled with the cause of death, serological test results, and precautions for handling. The packaging must mitigate contamination, safety hazards, prevent leakage, and maintain tissue integrity. The Secretary of Health and Human Services establishes requirements for non-transplant tissue bank licenses, including approval based on legal donation, proper screening for diseases, labeling, transportation, storage, and use according to donor authorization. The Secretary establishes requirements for non-transplant tissue bank licenses, ensuring compliance with standards to prevent communicable disease risks. The Secretary establishes requirements for exemption of human tissue specimens from certain regulations, prohibits falsely labeling or marking packages, and allows inspection of establishments for tissue preparation. Any authorized agent of a nationally recognized accrediting body can inspect establishments for human tissue preparation. The Attorney General and local law enforcement also retain inspection authority. Violations may result in the recall of human tissue specimens presenting a public hazard. The Secretary can order an immediate recall of a product that poses a public health hazard. Violating this order can result in a civil penalty of up to $10,000 per day, with penalties increasing annually based on the Consumer Price Index. (e) Penalties for Offenses: Violators may face up to 1 year in prison, a fine of up to $500, or both. Section 3571 of title 18, United States Code does not apply to offenses under this subsection.
(f) Construction With Other Laws: This Act does not affect, modify, repeal, or supersede any existing provisions under current Federal law.
(g) Human Tissue Specimen Defined: "Non-transplant tissue specimen" refers to legally donated anatomical specimens. "Non-transplant tissue specimen" refers to legally donated anatomical segments, cells, bodily fluids, or the complete body for medical research and education, excluding biological products under the Public Health Service Act.
